rev.comment: In most cases, no rationale. In any case, imroper use of covers/posters for filmography
rev.diff:
Line 59: Line 59:
===''Spartacus''===
===''Spartacus''===
{{Main|Spartacus (film)}}
{{Main|Spartacus (film)}}
â
[[Image:Spartacus sheetA.jpg|thumb|left|180px|'''Spartacus''']]
 
Upon his return to the [[United States]], Kubrick worked for six months on the [[Marlon Brando]] vehicle ''[[One-Eyed Jacks]]'' (1961). Brando eventually fired him and decided to direct the picture himself. The two had clashed over a number of casting decisions.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=fU78LdDClHUC&pg=PA164&vq=%22We%27ve+gotta+get+rid+of+kubrick%22&source=gbs_search_r&cad=1_1&sig=ACfU3U0VBh2pBtKj3CjazND_pY0DgQzBzw Stanley Kubrick By Vincent Lobrutto - Page 164] ISBN 9780306809064</ref> Kubrick worked on a number of unproduced screenplays<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?q=%22Lunatic+at+Large%2C+which+Kubrick+intended+to+develop+into+a+movie%22&btnG=Search+Books Heartbreak and Vine The Fate of Hardboiled Writers in Hollywood - Page 125] ISBN 9781852426781</ref> until [[Kirk Douglas]] asked him to take over Douglas' epic production ''[[Spartacus (film)|Spartacus]]'' (1960) from [[Anthony Mann]] who had been fired by the studio two weeks into shooting.
Upon his return to the [[United States]], Kubrick worked for six months on the [[Marlon Brando]] vehicle ''[[One-Eyed Jacks]]'' (1961). Brando eventually fired him and decided to direct the picture himself. The two had clashed over a number of casting decisions.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=fU78LdDClHUC&pg=PA164&vq=%22We%27ve+gotta+get+rid+of+kubrick%22&source=gbs_search_r&cad=1_1&sig=ACfU3U0VBh2pBtKj3CjazND_pY0DgQzBzw Stanley Kubrick By Vincent Lobrutto - Page 164] ISBN 9780306809064</ref> Kubrick worked on a number of unproduced screenplays<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?q=%22Lunatic+at+Large%2C+which+Kubrick+intended+to+develop+into+a+movie%22&btnG=Search+Books Heartbreak and Vine The Fate of Hardboiled Writers in Hollywood - Page 125] ISBN 9781852426781</ref> until [[Kirk Douglas]] asked him to take over Douglas' epic production ''[[Spartacus (film)|Spartacus]]'' (1960) from [[Anthony Mann]] who had been fired by the studio two weeks into shooting.
Line 70: Line 69:
===''Lolita''===
===''Lolita''===
{{Main|Lolita (1962 film)}}
{{Main|Lolita (1962 film)}}
â
[[Image:LolitaPoster.jpg|thumb|right|150px|'''Lolita''']]
 
In 1962, Kubrick moved to England to film ''[[Lolita (1962 film)|Lolita]]'' and he would reside there for the rest of his life. The film was Kubrick's first major controversy.<ref>[http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9901E6DD113AF937A35754C0A96F958260&scp=17&sq=stanley%20kubrick%20lolita&st=cse What They Say About Stanley Kubrick, The New York Times, July 4, 1999]</ref> The [[Lolita|book]], by Russian-American novelist [[Vladimir Nabokov]], dealt with an affair between a middle-aged man named Humbert Humbert and his twelve-year-old stepdaughter, and was already notorious as an "obscene" novel and a ''cause celebre'' when Kubrick embarked on the project. The difficult subject matter was mocked in the film's famous [[tagline]]: "How did they ever make a film of ''Lolita''?" Kubrick originally engaged Nabokov to adapt his own novel for the screen. The writer first produced a four-hundred page screenplay which he then reduced to two hundred.<ref name="Aragay">Mireia Aragay. page 113. [http://books.google.it/books?id=HqvBDYpaqsYC&hl=en Books in motion: adaptation, intertextuality, authorship]. Rodopi, 2005. ISBN 9789042019577</ref> The final screenplay was written by Kubrick himself, and it has been estimated that only 20% of Nabokov's work made it into the final draft.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?ei=Y17HSMv-GpmMjAHr-6nzCw&q=%22Kubrick+had+Nabokov+rewrite+a+shorter+version+of+the+screenplay+and+then+used+only+about+20+percent+of+this%22&btnG=Search+Books Stanley Kubrick, a Guide to References and Resources By Wallace Coyle]</ref> Nabokov's original draft was later published under the title ''Lolita: A Screenplay''.
In 1962, Kubrick moved to England to film ''[[Lolita (1962 film)|Lolita]]'' and he would reside there for the rest of his life. The film was Kubrick's first major controversy.<ref>[http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9901E6DD113AF937A35754C0A96F958260&scp=17&sq=stanley%20kubrick%20lolita&st=cse What They Say About Stanley Kubrick, The New York Times, July 4, 1999]</ref> The [[Lolita|book]], by Russian-American novelist [[Vladimir Nabokov]], dealt with an affair between a middle-aged man named Humbert Humbert and his twelve-year-old stepdaughter, and was already notorious as an "obscene" novel and a ''cause celebre'' when Kubrick embarked on the project. The difficult subject matter was mocked in the film's famous [[tagline]]: "How did they ever make a film of ''Lolita''?" Kubrick originally engaged Nabokov to adapt his own novel for the screen. The writer first produced a four-hundred page screenplay which he then reduced to two hundred.<ref name="Aragay">Mireia Aragay. page 113. [http://books.google.it/books?id=HqvBDYpaqsYC&hl=en Books in motion: adaptation, intertextuality, authorship]. Rodopi, 2005. ISBN 9789042019577</ref> The final screenplay was written by Kubrick himself, and it has been estimated that only 20% of Nabokov's work made it into the final draft.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?ei=Y17HSMv-GpmMjAHr-6nzCw&q=%22Kubrick+had+Nabokov+rewrite+a+shorter+version+of+the+screenplay+and+then+used+only+about+20+percent+of+this%22&btnG=Search+Books Stanley Kubrick, a Guide to References and Resources By Wallace Coyle]</ref> Nabokov's original draft was later published under the title ''Lolita: A Screenplay''.
Line 81: Line 79:
===''Dr. Strangelove''===
===''Dr. Strangelove''===
{{Main|Dr. Strangelove}}
{{Main|Dr. Strangelove}}
â
[[Image:Drstrangelove1sheet-.jpg|thumb|left|200px|''Dr. Strangelove or How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb'']]
 
Kubrick's next film, ''[[Dr. Strangelove|Dr. Strangelove or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb]]'' (1964), became a [[cult film]] and is now considered a classic. The screenplayâbased upon the novel ''[[Red Alert (novel)|Red Alert]]'', by ex-RAF flight lieutenant [[Peter George]] (writing as Peter Bryant)âwas co-written by Kubrick and George, with contributions by American satirist [[Terry Southern]]. ''Red Alert'' is a serious, cautionary tale of accidental atomic war. However, Kubrick found the conditions leading to nuclear war so absurd that the story became a sinister macabre comedy. Once so reconceived, Kubrick recruited Terry Southern to polish the final screenplay.
Kubrick's next film, ''[[Dr. Strangelove|Dr. Strangelove or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb]]'' (1964), became a [[cult film]] and is now considered a classic. The screenplayâbased upon the novel ''[[Red Alert (novel)|Red Alert]]'', by ex-RAF flight lieutenant [[Peter George]] (writing as Peter Bryant)âwas co-written by Kubrick and George, with contributions by American satirist [[Terry Southern]]. ''Red Alert'' is a serious, cautionary tale of accidental atomic war. However, Kubrick found the conditions leading to nuclear war so absurd that the story became a sinister macabre comedy. Once so reconceived, Kubrick recruited Terry Southern to polish the final screenplay.
Line 92: Line 89:
===''2001: A Space Odyssey''===
===''2001: A Space Odyssey''===
{{Main|2001: A Space Odyssey (film)}}
{{Main|2001: A Space Odyssey (film)}}
â
[[Image:2001Style_B.jpg|thumb|right|325px|''2001: A Space Odyssey'']]
 
Kubrick spent five years developing his next film, ''[[2001: A Space Odyssey (film)|2001: A Space Odyssey]]'' (1968). The film was conceived as a [[Cinerama]] spectacle and was photographed in [[Super Panavision 70]]. Kubrick co-wrote the screenplay with science fiction writer Sir [[Arthur C. Clarke]], expanding on Clarke's short story "[[The Sentinel (short story)|The Sentinel]]". Kubrick reportedly told Clarke that his intention was to make "the proverbial great science-fiction film."
Kubrick spent five years developing his next film, ''[[2001: A Space Odyssey (film)|2001: A Space Odyssey]]'' (1968). The film was conceived as a [[Cinerama]] spectacle and was photographed in [[Super Panavision 70]]. Kubrick co-wrote the screenplay with science fiction writer Sir [[Arthur C. Clarke]], expanding on Clarke's short story "[[The Sentinel (short story)|The Sentinel]]". Kubrick reportedly told Clarke that his intention was to make "the proverbial great science-fiction film."
Line 113: Line 109:
===''A Clockwork Orange''===
===''A Clockwork Orange''===
{{Main|A Clockwork Orange (film)}}
{{Main|A Clockwork Orange (film)}}
â
[[Image:Clockwork'71.jpg|thumb|left|225px|[[Malcolm McDowell]] as [[Alex DeLarge]] in ''A Clockwork Orange'']]
 
After ''2001'', Kubrick initially attempted to make a film about the life of [[Napoleon Bonaparte]]. When financing fell through, Kubrick went looking for a project which he could film quickly on a small budget. He eventually settled on ''[[A Clockwork Orange (film)|A Clockwork Orange]]'' (1971). His adaptation of Anthony Burgess' novel is a dark, shocking exploration of violence in human society. The film was initially released with an 'X' [[motion picture rating systems|rating]] in the [[United States]], and caused considerable controversy.
After ''2001'', Kubrick initially attempted to make a film about the life of [[Napoleon Bonaparte]]. When financing fell through, Kubrick went looking for a project which he could film quickly on a small budget. He eventually settled on ''[[A Clockwork Orange (film)|A Clockwork Orange]]'' (1971). His adaptation of Anthony Burgess' novel is a dark, shocking exploration of violence in human society. The film was initially released with an 'X' [[motion picture rating systems|rating]] in the [[United States]], and caused considerable controversy.
Line 143: Line 138:
===''The Shining''===
===''The Shining''===
{{Main|The Shining (film)}}
{{Main|The Shining (film)}}
â
[[Image:The shining heres johnny.jpg|upright|thumb|left|Jack Nicholson in ''The Shining'']]
 
The pace of Kubrick's work slowed considerably after ''Barry Lyndon'', and he did not make another film for five years. ''[[The Shining (film)|The Shining]]'', released in 1980, was adapted from the [[The Shining (novel)|novel]] of the same name by bestselling horror writer [[Stephen King]]. The film starred [[Jack Nicholson]] as Jack Torrance, a failed writer who takes a job as an off-season caretaker of the [[Overlook Hotel]], a high-class resort deep in the Colorado mountains. The job demands spending the winter in the isolated hotel with his wife Wendy, played by [[Shelley Duvall]], and their young son, Danny, who is gifted with a form of [[telepathy]] – the "shining" of the film's title.
The pace of Kubrick's work slowed considerably after ''Barry Lyndon'', and he did not make another film for five years. ''[[The Shining (film)|The Shining]]'', released in 1980, was adapted from the [[The Shining (novel)|novel]] of the same name by bestselling horror writer [[Stephen King]]. The film starred [[Jack Nicholson]] as Jack Torrance, a failed writer who takes a job as an off-season caretaker of the [[Overlook Hotel]], a high-class resort deep in the Colorado mountains. The job demands spending the winter in the isolated hotel with his wife Wendy, played by [[Shelley Duvall]], and their young son, Danny, who is gifted with a form of [[telepathy]] – the "shining" of the film's title.
Line 158: Line 152:
===''Full Metal Jacket''===
===''Full Metal Jacket''===
{{Main|Full Metal Jacket}}
{{Main|Full Metal Jacket}}
â
[[Image:Full Metal Jacket- 1987.jpg|thumb|right|200px|''Full Metal Jacket'']]
 
It was seven years until Kubrick's next film, ''[[Full Metal Jacket]]'' (1987), an adaptation of [[Gustav Hasford]]'s [[Vietnam War]] novel, ''[[The Short-Timers]],'' starring [[Matthew Modine]] as Joker, [[Adam Baldwin]] as Animal Mother, [[R. Lee Ermey]] as [[Gunnery Sergeant]] Hartman, and [[Vincent D'Onofrio]] as [[Private (rank)|Private]] Leonard "[[Gomer Pyle]]" Lawrence. Kubrick said to film critic [[Gene Siskel]] that his attraction to Gustav Hasford's book was because it was "neither anti-war or pro-war", held "no moral or political position", and was primarily concerned with "the way things are."
It was seven years until Kubrick's next film, ''[[Full Metal Jacket]]'' (1987), an adaptation of [[Gustav Hasford]]'s [[Vietnam War]] novel, ''[[The Short-Timers]],'' starring [[Matthew Modine]] as Joker, [[Adam Baldwin]] as Animal Mother, [[R. Lee Ermey]] as [[Gunnery Sergeant]] Hartman, and [[Vincent D'Onofrio]] as [[Private (rank)|Private]] Leonard "[[Gomer Pyle]]" Lawrence. Kubrick said to film critic [[Gene Siskel]] that his attraction to Gustav Hasford's book was because it was "neither anti-war or pro-war", held "no moral or political position", and was primarily concerned with "the way things are."
Line 171: Line 164:
===''Eyes Wide Shut''===
===''Eyes Wide Shut''===
{{Main|Eyes Wide Shut}}
{{Main|Eyes Wide Shut}}
â
[[Image:Eyes Wide Shut.jpg|thumb|left|200px|''Eyes Wide Shut'']]
 
Kubrick's final film was ''[[Eyes Wide Shut]]'', starring then-married actors [[Tom Cruise]] and [[Nicole Kidman]] as a wealthy Manhattan couple on a sexual odyssey.
Kubrick's final film was ''[[Eyes Wide Shut]]'', starring then-married actors [[Tom Cruise]] and [[Nicole Kidman]] as a wealthy Manhattan couple on a sexual odyssey.
